content.question: Substance Normal boiling point <math alttext="H F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="293 kelvins" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mn>293</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mrow><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="F 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="85 kelvins" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>85</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> The electron cloud of <math alttext="H F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is smaller than that of <math alttext="F 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> , however, <math alttext="H F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> has a much higher boiling point than <math alttext="F 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> has. Which of the following explains how the dispersion-force model of intermolecular attraction does not account for the unusually high boiling point of <math alttext="H F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>?

choices.label: <math alttext="F 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is soluble in water, whereas <math alttext="H F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is insoluble in water.

The <math alttext="F 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> molecule has a greater mass than the <math alttext="H F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> molecule has.

Liquid <math alttext="F 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> has weak dispersion force attractions between its molecules, whereas liquid <math alttext="H F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> has strong ionic interactions between <math alttext="H with a positive one charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="F with a negative one charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>âˆ’</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> ions.

Liquid <math alttext="F 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> has weak dispersion force attractions between its molecules, whereas liquid <math alttext="H F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> has both weak dispersion force attractions and hydrogen bonding interactions between its molecules.

content.answer: Liquid <math alttext="F 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> has weak dispersion force attractions between its molecules, whereas liquid <math alttext="H F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> has both weak dispersion force attractions and hydrogen bonding interactions between its molecules.

skill.text: 4.D: Explain the degree to which a model or representation describes the connection between particulate-level properties and macroscopic properties.
